The legislation is aimed at limiting what can be taught in classrooms about sexual orientation and gender identity, and also gives parents the right to sue schools or teachers if they believe what is being taught is unacceptable.

headline: Man Charged With Pushing a Capitol Police Officer Over a Ledge on Jan. 6
text: A New York man was arrested on Wednesday and charged with shoving a Capitol Police officer over a ledge on Jan. 6, 2021, when a mob of Trump supporters disrupted Congress as it was certifying the 2020 election results, prosecutors said.

headline: Michael Flynn Invokes Fifth Amendment Before Jan. 6 Panel
text: WASHINGTON — The House committee investigating the Jan. 6 attack on the Capitol ran into a familiar roadblock on Thursday as yet another high-profile witness invoked his right against self-incrimination rather than answer questions about the events that led to a mob assault on Congress.

headline: Biden Urges Americans to Blame Rising Prices on Putin. Many Do, for Now.
text: WASHINGTON — The price of gasoline has risen every day since Russia invaded Ukraine. Record-high inflation in the United States is causing sticker shock. And now, President Biden is blaming the pinch on Vladimir V. Putin, the Russian president.

headline: Security Lapses Led to Deadly Attack on Base in Kenya, Inquiry Finds
text: A Pentagon investigation concluded that inadequate security and intelligence practices contributed to the deaths of three Americans during a 2020 assault on the Manda Bay military base by Shabab fighters.

headline: Russia Batters and Encircles Ukrainian Cities, as Diplomacy Falters
text: The top diplomats of Russia and Ukraine failed to make even a hint of progress Thursday in their first face-to-face meeting since the Russian invasion began, while Russian bombardments spread more carnage in a two-week-old war that Ukraine estimated had already inflicted $100 billion in damage.

headline: U.S. Fights Bioweapons Disinformation Pushed by Russia and China
text: WASHINGTON — One of Russia’s most incendiary disinformation campaigns ramped up days ago, when its defense and foreign ministries issued statements falsely claiming that the Pentagon was financing biological weapons labs in Ukraine.

headline: If the Lockout Makes Baseball Better, It Will Have Been Worth It
text: At last, it is safe to say the only three words fans have cared about for months: Baseball is back. Major League Baseball and its players’ union reached an agreement Thursday on a collective bargaining agreement after 99 locked-out days of tedious rhetoric and posturing. Put ’em in, coach. They’re ready to play.

headline: Jussie Smollett Sentenced to Jail for False Report of a Hate Crime
text: A judge in Chicago sentenced Jussie Smollett to five months in jail on Thursday, ordering that the actor be incarcerated for falsely reporting to the police that he had been the victim of a racist and homophobic attack in 2019.

headline: Emilio Delgado, Luis on ‘Sesame Street’ for Four Decades, Dies at 81
text: Emilio Delgado, the actor who played Luis the handyman on the beloved children’s television show “Sesame Street” for more than four decades, died on Thursday at his home in Manhattan. He was 81.

headline: What’s the Best Way to Cope in an Anxious World? Do Something.
text: Many people are experiencing a jumbled mix of emotions right now. There’s sadness and a feeling of helplessness about the brutal attacks against the people of Ukraine, as well as anxiety and fear about the threat of nuclear weapons. Add to that exhaustion after two years of worrying about a deadly virus. And for some, there’s also guilt, for the indulgence of talking about anxious feelings at a time when others are suffering far more.

headline: Flu Vaccine Was Not Very Effective This Season, the C.D.C. Says
text: This season’s flu vaccine has offered little to no protection against getting a mild or moderate case of influenza, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention said this week.

headline: Tommy Fleetwood Loses His Beard, Finds a Place Atop the Leaderboard
text: PONTE VEDRA BEACH, Fla. — Tommy Fleetwood, a golfer once ranked in the men’s top 10, has been missing from a PGA Tour leaderboard for so long, fans may not have recognized him when he vaulted into first place during the first round at the Players Championship here on Thursday.

headline: Prosecutors to Drop Murder Charge in Fatal Shooting After Right-Wing Rally in Denver
text: Prosecutors said on Thursday that they planned to drop a second-degree murder charge against a former security guard for a Denver television news station who fatally shot a man in a confrontation after a right-wing rally in 2020.

headline: Parisienne Scoop
text: FRIDAY PUZZLE — I was about three months into writing Wordplay when Robyn Weintraub made her debut in the New York Times Crossword in 2011. There was a dearth of women constructors being published — there still is — so I was happy to see Ms. Weintraub join our ranks.

headline: Variety: Acrostic
text: ACROSTIC — Once I figured out the unusual second word in this acrostic, at the very end of my solve, I felt a strong sense of déjà vu. Didn’t we just see it in another puzzle? Well, not quite; it appeared in the clue set of an acrostic from 21 years ago. The curiosities of memory and time go well with the source of today’s passage, which is a book by Alan Burdick called “Why Time Flies: A Mostly Scientific Investigation,” from 2017.

headline: Jussie Smollett Sentenced to Five Months in Jail
text: The actor reiterated his innocence in court after Judge James B. Linn ordered him to be incarcerated for falsely reporting to the police that he had been the victim of a racist and homophobic attack in 2019.

headline: Congress Clears $1.5 Trillion Spending Bill, Including Ukraine Aid
text: WASHINGTON — Congress cleared the first major federal spending legislation of President Biden’s administration on Thursday, approving a $1.5 trillion measure with substantial increases for domestic and national security programs, along with $13.6 billion in emergency aid for Ukraine as it battles Russia’s invasion.

headline: Requests for compassionate release filed by federal prisoners swelled during the pandemic, a study finds.
text: The number of requests for compassionate release filed by federal prisoners skyrocketed during the pandemic, according to a report by the U.S. Sentencing Commission released on Thursday, with risks associated with contracting Covid-19 a critical factor.

headline: Climate Change’s Threat to the Glorious Redwood, Both Here and Afar
text: Framed by native eucalyptuses and ferns in a shady glade near Victoria’s famed Great Ocean Road, a group of Californian giants rises into the Australian sun.

headline: Russia-Ukraine talks come to nothing as bombardment of cities continues.
text: Russian and Ukrainian foreign ministers failed to make any progress Thursday in their first face-to-face meeting since the Russian invasion began two weeks ago, while Russian bombardments spread more carnage, having caused an estimated $100 billion in damage so far.

headline: Congress approves $13.6 billion in emergency aid for Ukraine.
text: WASHINGTON — Congress passed a major spending bill on Thursday that includes $13.6 billion in emergency aid for Ukraine as it battles Russia’s invasion.

headline: Biden will call for suspending normal trade relations with Russia.
text: President Biden will announce on Friday that the United States will join the G7 and the European Union in calling for the suspension of normal trade relations with Russia, according to a person familiar with the announcement, a change that would raise tariffs for many Russian products.

headline: Playing Sidekick, Each Found Their Soul Mate
text: When Jason William Capps agreed to accompany his best friend on a casual date in late 2010, it was after being promised that the woman his friend was meeting would bring a companion of her own. That companion was Stephanie Onyinye Osimiri.

headline: Opening Up to Marriage, and Motherhood
text: Before Deborah Shih-Chi Hsieh left her apartment in Washington at the beginning of the pandemic and moved back into her parents’ home in Tempe, Ariz., she had a job that offered little flexibility when it came to dating.

headline: From Their High School Lockers to ‘Forever’
text: GiAnna Katherine Wyatt had recently moved from Louisville, Ky., to Lantana, Fla., when she met Kyle Gregory Orangio at the lockers in their school, Santaluces Community High School in Lantana, in August 2004. Though Mr. Orangio stood 6-foot-6 and towered over her 5-foot-2 frame, Ms. Wyatt said he at first seemed shy and quiet.

headline: When My Heart Broke, My Father Used Google to Save Me
text: After I came home from the hospital, my mother and father took turns sitting on my bed every night to make sure I was still breathing. My mother would rest her head on my chest and say a prayer. My father would whisper, “I love you,” and touch my cheek.

headline: Those Lucky Coins Paid Off
text: Binge more Vows columns here and read all our wedding, relationship and divorce coverage here.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Black History Lives in a 3-Story House on Staten Island
text: “This is a motherlode of information, with so many stories that have never been told. That’s the purpose of my collection: to educate, heal, inspire and empower.”

headline: Corrections: March 11, 2022
text: A picture caption with an article on Thursday about the former mayor of Atlanta and civil rights activist Andrew Young, using information from The Associated Press, misidentified a person standing with Mr. Young and the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. It was the Rev. Hosea Williams, not Ralph D. Abernathy.

headline: Your Friday Briefing
text: The Russian and Ukrainian foreign ministers failed to make any progress yesterday in their first face-to-face meeting since the Russian invasion began two weeks ago, while Russian bombardments spread more carnage, having caused an estimated $100 billion in damage so far. Follow the latest updates here.

headline: For Young Ukrainians, Independence Is Not Optional
text: We asked young Ukrainians what it meant to them to grow up in an independent Ukraine and how it feels to watch Russia wage war on their homeland.

headline: Late Night Casts Doubt on the Russian-Ukrainian Peace Talks
text: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.

headline: Word of the Day: tête-à-tête
text: The word tête-à-tête has appeared in six articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Sept. 23 in “Finding Redemption and Rebirth on the Road to Broadway” by Salamishah Tillet:

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
text: FRIDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.

headline: How Medical Care for Transgender Youth Became ‘Child Abuse’ in Texas
text: HOUSTON — Jeffrey Younger fought for years with his ex-wife, a pediatrician, over the gender identity of one of their twins. While she followed the advice of their children’s doctor to affirm the child’s desire to dress as a girl, grow long hair and be known as Luna, Mr. Younger steadfastly objected.

headline: As Ireland’s Church Retreats, the Cult of a Female Saint Thrives
text: KILDARE, Ireland — Around the year 480, as legend has it, a freed slave named Brigid founded a convent under an oak in the east of Ireland. To feed her followers, she asked the King of Leinster, who ruled the area, for a grant of land.

headline: Chinese stocks listed in U.S. tumble over fears of potential delisting
text: Chinese stocks listed in the United States saw their worst day of trading since 2008 on Thursday, driven by fears of potential delisting in U.S. markets under a law that requires the companies to hand over audit information to American regulators. Reverberations were felt in Chinese markets on Friday, where many shares had sharp declines.

headline: Two years after declaring a pandemic, the W.H.O.’s watchword is still caution.
text: The World Health Organization, often criticized for being too slow to declare in 2020 that a pandemic was underway, now says — two years to the day after making that declaration — that many countries are being too quick to declare it over and let down their guard.

headline: Russian Sanctions Snarl Shipping Even as Pandemic Pressure Eases
text: Russian ships banned from docking in Britain. Cargo containers piling up at European ports. Airfreight rerouted around Ukraine and Russia.

headline: China Has Tools to Help Russia’s Economy. None Are Big Enough to Save It.
text: When the United States and its allies declared a financial war on Russia after its invasion of Ukraine, the world turned to see what China would do.

headline: ‘Arpology’
text: A song from the Daily episode “On the Road with Ukraine’s Refugees.” Composed by Marion Lozano.

headline: ‘Slow Burn’
text: A song from the Daily episode “On the Road with Ukraine’s Refugees.” Composed by Marion Lozano.

headline: Where $5 Trillion in Pandemic Stimulus Money Went
text: It is the largest government relief effort in recorded history, and two years after Covid-19 crisis began, money is still flowing to communities. Here’s where it went and how it was spent.

headline: Welcome to Londongrad, Where Kleptocrats Wash Their Money Clean
text: Britain is having a hard time quitting its addiction to Russian money.

headline: Audiobooks
text: Do you listen to audiobooks? Is it a better (or worse) experience than reading a physical book? Why do you prefer one option over the other? What are some of your favorite audiobooks?

headline: Do You Keep a Journal?
text: Do you have a journal or diary? If so, what do you like to write about in it and why? Do you use it to keep track of joyful, difficult or memorable events in your life? Do you use it to process feelings? Give gratitude? Practice self-care? Do something else?

headline: A Novelist Evokes a Real-Life Family of Actors, and One Famous Assassin
text: BOOTHBy Karen Joy Fowler

headline: The Democrats’ Historic Successes and Contemporary Failures
text: WHAT IT TOOK TO WINA History of the Democratic PartyBy Michael KazinLEFT BEHINDThe Democrats’ Failed Attempt to Solve InequalityBy Lily Geismer

headline: New in Paperback: ‘A Little Devil in America’ and ‘My Friend Anna’
text: ANTIQUITIES, by Cynthia Ozick. (Vintage, 272 pp., $16.) The Times critic Dwight Garner noted that this collection of five stories may be a small addition to Ozick’s voluminous body of work, but it’s one that is “richly patterned and strongly colored.” The titular story, a novella set in 1949, follows a retired lawyer as he joins six other semi-distinguished old men to write accounts of their time at a defunct patrician boys’ academy.

headline: Boycotts, Not Bombs: Sanctions Are a Go-To Tactic, With Uneven Results
text: Financial, travel and trade penalties have become common tools to combat warfare and human rights abuses, but they have not always met their stated goals.

headline: 5 Things to Do This Weekend
text: Selections from the current Weekend section, including a review of the film “Turning Red.”

headline: The New York Times News Quiz, March 11, 2022
text: Did you follow the news this week? Take our quiz to see how well you stack up with other Times readers.

headline: Lesson of the Day: ‘How the Lab-Grown Chicken Is Made’
text: This lesson is a part of our Accessible Activities feature, which aims to welcome a wider variety of learners to our site and to The Times. Learn more and tell us what you think here.

headline: Putin Wants a Clash of Civilizations. Is ‘The West’ Falling for It?
text: BERLIN — Amid the point-blank horror of Russia’s invasion of Ukraine, the expanding war zone in Europe seems to have become a comfort zone for much of America’s political establishment. In his State of the Union address, President Biden declared that in the face of Vladimir Putin’s aggression, “we see a more unified Europe, a more unified West.” He is correct. Polish nationalists and European Union bureaucrats are sudden brothers in arms. Back at home, Republicans and Democrats have put aside differences on climate change and voting rights for an enemy who appears to have emerged from Cold War central casting: An evil empire is again on the march in Europe.

headline: Is This Finally the Year of the Electric Car?
text: Last summer, Hank Gutman, serving as New York’s transportation commissioner, encountered a couple in the Bronx who were charging their Nissan Leaf, running an extension cord out of their apartment window and across the sidewalk. Mr. Gutman was already very concerned about current infrastructure supporting electric vehicles in the city, but this moment had a crystallizing effect. To convert New York City into an electric-car mecca was a very different prospect from turning the tides in suburban New Jersey.

headline: ‘Wozzeck,’ the 20th Century’s Most Influential Opera, Turns 100
text: Theodor Adorno had to commiserate with Alban Berg late into the night on Dec. 14, 1925, after the premiere of “Wozzeck” at the Berlin State Opera.

headline: Demystifying the Uncertainty of Snowfall
text: A snowstorm is lurching across the country, up the coast or maybe in your area. The local meteorologist predicts 12 to 18 inches of snow, and the weather forecast stirs excitement and preparation: Nervous shoppers clear out the grocery store. Schools close. Maybe the trains shut down.

headline: ‘He Got a Cigarette Stuck in His Neck, and He Took It Like a Man.’
text: A common joke in crime fiction circles is that asking “What is noir?” will result in hours of unending argument. (I tend to go by the writer Jack Bludis’s definition: “hard-boiled = tough, noir = screwed.”) Eli Cranor’s top-shelf debut, DON’T KNOW TOUGH (Soho Crime, 322 pp., $24.95), is unmistakably noir in the Southern tradition, a cauldron of terrible choices and even more terrible outcomes.

headline: How Millions of Lives Might Have Been Saved From Covid-19
text: This article is part of Times Opinion’s reflection on the two-year mark of the Covid pandemic. Read more in a note from Alexandra Sifferlin, Opinion’s health and science editor, in our Opinion Today newsletter.

headline: The Supreme Court Did the Right Thing. I’m Still Worried.
text: State legislatures are, and always have been, creatures of state constitutions, bound by the terms of those constitutions and subject to the judgments of state courts.

headline: Putin Is ‘Profoundly Anti-Modern.’ Masha Gessen Explains What That Means for the World.
text: For Western audiences, the past few weeks have been a torrent of information about what’s happening in Russia and Ukraine. Daily updates of Russian military advances. Horrifying videos of buildings exploding and innocent civilians being killed. Announcements of increasingly severe economic sanctions and major corporate pullouts. Charts showing the collapse of the ruble. Story after story about the hardships facing the Russian economy.

headline: How to Buy a Vacant Lot
text: To Vicky and Mickey Popat, it seemed as if everyone in Orlando, Fla., wanted to buy a house last spring. “The market here was so skimpy that any time a decent property got listed, it would receive multiple offers right away and get snatched up,” said Ms. Popat, 39.

headline: As the Omicron Wave Subsides, Travel Insurance Claims Crawl
text: Before the pandemic, Lauren Mack, 44, a writer based in New York City, “did not routinely purchase travel insurance,” she wrote in an email. Covid-19 convinced her otherwise, and of six trips taken since the onset of the pandemic, she has had to file claims for three — twice for weather delays and once because her travel companion tested positive for the virus. Two are still under review, and the first took nearly two months from claim to reimbursement.

headline: How a Gallery Owner Spends Her Sundays
text: As the owner of Bernd Goeckler, an art gallery in Greenwich Village, Katja Hirche curates a cutting-edge collection of contemporary artworks and antique furnishings.

headline: Rupert Grint of ‘Harry Potter’ Gets His Own Glasses
text: Rupert Grint covered his left eye with his hand and attempted to read the top few lines. “E, D, F, C, E, F,” he said slowly.

headline: Help! How Do I Get My Sex Drive Back?
text: Q: Are there any proven treatments for low libido in women?

headline: Bracing for Losses, Democrats Look to Biden for a Reset
text: PHILADELPHIA — House Democrats planned a retreat here this week hoping for a reset after a difficult period during which President Biden has been buffeted by rising gas prices, soaring inflation and sagging approval ratings.

headline: The Ukrainian Cyberwar That Wasn’t
text: Late last year, the United States and Britain sent experts to Ukraine to help its government prepare for the spectacular cyberattack that some believed would be Vladimir Putin’s opening salvo during an invasion. Ukraine’s electricity grid was said to be a particularly attractive target for Russian hackers, who managed to shut it down for brief periods twice before.

headline: Even Before War, Thousands Were Fleeing Russia for the U.S.
text: LOS ANGELES — Last fall, Iuliia Shuvalova and Sergei Ignatev, a young Russian couple, sold their car and took out a loan to pay for a holiday at a beach resort on Mexico’s Riviera Maya.

headline: Apps and Oranges: Behind Apple’s ‘Bullying’ on Trademarks
text: When Genevieve St. John started a sex-and-life coaching blog in 2019, she designed a logo for the business of a neon green and pink apple, which was cut open to resemble female genitalia.

headline: AmfAR Heads to Billionaires Row in Palm Beach
text: The AIDS charity group amfAR usually holds a gala during New York Fashion Week in February, but that was shelved because of the Omicron variant. So when art collectors John and Amy Phelan offered to host a fund-raiser at their modern, 17,000-square-foot estate in Palm Beach, Fla., last Saturday, the money followed.

headline: Millions in Stimulus Aid, and Clashing Over How to Spend It
text: Last June, a meeting of the Dutchess County Legislature in New York’s Hudson Valley quickly turned heated over how to spend some of the county’s $57 million in federal pandemic relief aid.

headline: Pompeii Moves With the Times
text: POMPEII, Italy — On a recent morning at the necropolis of Porta Sarno, just outside Pompeii’s eastern edge, Mattia Buondonno gingerly raised a protective tarp covering a tomb discovered last year.

headline: At 101, and After 36 Years as Mayor, ‘Hurricane Hazel’ Is Still a Force in Canada
text: MISSISSAUGA, Ontario — On Valentine’s Day, she first took a call from Justin Trudeau. Next, she joined Ontario’s premier at the unveiling of a new commuter train line to be named in her honor.

headline: Welcome to Londongrad, Where Kleptocrats Wash Their Money Clean
text: These are, to say the least, uncomfortable times to be a Russian oligarch.

headline: He’s Springing Forward to Move City Clocks to Daylight Time
text: Good morning. It’s Friday. We’ll look at how New York City’s clock master handles the change to daylight saving time. We’ll also check on a telephone number made famous by a song in the big band era.

headline: An Indian state that Covid once hit hard is now recording sharply lower deaths.
text: Throughout several devastating waves of the pandemic in India, some public hospitals in the western state of Maharashtra were so overwhelmed that doctors had to treat patients in hallways. But in recent weeks the state, home to Mumbai, has made remarkable progress in sharply reducing its caseload, with the region on Wednesday reporting no daily Covid deaths for the third time this month.

headline: Australian Police Officer Acquitted in Death of Indigenous Teenager
text: MELBOURNE, Australia — A police officer in Australia was found not guilty on Friday in the death of a 19-year-old Indigenous man whose shooting more than two years ago prompted widespread protests and worsened long-simmering tensions over the government’s treatment of the country’s native peoples.

headline: Lockdowns spread in China as the virus surges in Shanghai and over a dozen provinces.
text: BEIJING — Cinemas, theaters and museums have closed in downtown Shanghai, and tickets have been refunded. The vast city’s school system announced late Friday that it would switch to online learning. And across China, more than 100 neighborhoods have been labeled medium-risk or high-risk Covid zones, with frequent mandatory testing and partial or complete lockdowns.

headline: Putin’s Endgame: A Conversation With Fiona Hill
text: Ending the war in Ukraine very much depends on how and when President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia allows it to end.

headline: ‘Economic War’
text: It’s hard to think of a precedent: The British government yesterday ordered Chelsea — one of the world’s most glamorous soccer clubs and Europe’s defending champion — to stop conducting almost all its business operations.

headline: India Election Victory Is Expanding a Hindu Monk’s National Profile
text: GORAKHPUR, India — The powerful chief minister of India’s most populous state woke up at a Hindu temple, fed cows sweet jaggery cakes, performed a religious ceremony for Lord Shiva, then hit the trail on the last day of his election campaign this month.

headline: An inquiry into the U.K. government’s pandemic response will include a focus on bereaved families.
text: A public inquiry into the British government’s handling of the coronavirus crisis will aim to understand the experiences of bereaved families and disparities in the effect of the pandemic on different groups, Prime Minister Boris Johnson said on Thursday.

headline: A secret ad deal between Google and Meta is under scrutiny in Europe.
text: A secret deal struck between Google and Meta, the parent company of Facebook, is being investigated by antitrust regulators in the European Union and Britain for potentially undermining competition in the multibillion-dollar digital advertising market.

headline: A Brewing Rivalry Goes the Nets’ Way, for One Night
text: Philadelphia turned out to celebrate and express itself in its own inimitable way. Around the time that Julius Erving and Allen Iverson were sharing a courtside hug, 76ers fans at the Wells Fargo Center were filing into the arena so they could boo Ben Simmons, a former member of their team, as he warmed up for a game in which he would not play.

headline: An Israeli Skier Shines, but Does Not Compromise, at the Paralympics
text: YANQING, China — Just as it was becoming clear that Sheina Vaspi had the talent and drive to compete internationally, she faced a difficult choice.

headline: Strong Late-Winter Storm Knocks Out Power and Snarls Travel
text: A fast-moving winter storm brought high winds and heavy snowfall to a wide stretch of the eastern United States on Saturday, knocking out power to thousands and disrupting travel with hazardous conditions, meteorologists said.

headline: Russian Demands to Ease Sanctions Halt Nuclear Talks With Iran
text: BRUSSELS — Russian demands that a revised nuclear agreement with Iran shield it from sanctions imposed because of its war in Ukraine halted efforts to revive the deal on Friday, just as negotiators said they had all but finalized the agreement.

headline: Wall Street Joins the Unbanking of Russia
text: Goldman Sachs yesterday became the first major global bank to say it was quitting Russia, followed shortly after by JPMorgan Chase. The Wall Street giants join a growing list of multinational companies that have pledged to stop doing business in Russia. “None of us can fail to see this for what it is: the invasion of a sovereign state,” David Solomon, Goldman’s C.E.O., wrote in a memo to employees.

headline: Your Induction Stove Is the First Step Toward Plugging In the Whole House
text: Of all the energy hogs in Joseph Mulvaney’s home, his gas range was not the biggest offender. But earlier this month, he replaced it with an induction one anyway.

headline: ‘The Batman’ | Anatomy of a Scene
text: Matt Reeves narrates a sequence from his film, starring Robert Pattinson.

headline: Watch Robert Pattinson Take Flight in ‘The Batman’
text: In “Anatomy of a Scene,” we ask directors to reveal the secrets that go into making key scenes in their movies. See new episodes in the series on Fridays. You can also watch our collection of more than 150 videos on YouTube and subscribe to our YouTube channel.

headline: Leo Marx, 102, Dies; Studied Clash of Nature and Culture in America
text: Leo Marx, a cultural historian whose landmark book exploring the pervasive intrusion of technology on nature helped define the field of American studies, died on Tuesday at his home in Boston. He was 102.

headline: Australia considers lifting its quarantine requirement for close contacts of infected people.
text: Australia is considering relaxing its pandemic rules, including quarantine requirements for close contacts of people who test positive for the coronavirus, as the country shifts from trying to prevent transmission entirely to protecting those at risk of severe illness, health officials said on Friday.

headline: The Inside Story of How a ‘Bogus’ Letter Roiled Britain
text: Serial Productions spent years reporting on a British scandal that has had far-reaching consequences. Here’s what the team found.

headline: Leaders of Sarah Everard Vigil Had Rights Violated by Police, Court Rules
text: LONDON — The London police violated the human rights of the organizers behind a March 2021 vigil for a woman who was killed by a serving police officer as she walked home, the British High Court ruled on Friday, a decision that comes as the government seeks greater authority for the police to block protests.

headline: Transcript: Ezra Klein Interviews Masha Gessen
text: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like today’s episode with Masha Gessen. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.

headline: A Brief History of Bras in Crosswords
text: This is Clued In, a column that will give you insight into some of the New York Times Crossword clues and answers.

headline: Government Site for Buying Savings Bonds Shows Its Age
text: As inflation has surged, many consumers have turned to the federal government’s online TreasuryDirect system to buy inflation-indexed savings bonds. But the 20-year-old website may be showing its age.

headline: ‘Magic Could Happen’
text: THOUSAND OAKS, Calif. — The country’s fastest high school distance runners were circling the track on a recent weeknight as Andrew Young dangled from the back of a speeding golf cart with his camera. Young’s twin sons, Lex and Leo, whose YouTube channel has nearly 13,000 followers, had enlisted their father to record their team’s workout for posterity. The problem was they kept outrunning the golf cart.

headline: Europe’s Trains Take Fighters to Ukraine, and Bring Back Refugees
text: ABOARD THE PRAGUE-PRZEMYSL TRAIN — On the 12th night of the war, on a platform at Prague’s central train station, Vitali Slobodianiuk and Volodymyr Kotsyuba met for the first time.

headline: The Latest News From Ukraine and California’s Response
text: Given the fast-changing situation in Ukraine and the mounting death toll, I’ll be using today’s newsletter to guide you through our coverage of the war as well as some stories with particular relevance to California readers.

headline: A Tale of Survival Surfaces as an 1891 Shipwreck Is Found in Lake Superior
text: On May 4, 1891, as gale-force winds and waves raged on Lake Superior, the crew of a schooner barge named Atlanta abandoned ship as it sank. The six men and one woman, a cook, clung to their lifeboat for nine hours, fighting at its oars to guide it to the Michigan shore.

headline: The Mafia’s View of ‘The Godfather’ and the W.N.B.A. Star Detained in Russia: The Week in Narrated Articles
text: This weekend, listen to a collection of narrated articles from around The New York Times, read aloud by the reporters who wrote them.

headline: Ask Wirecutter: Dog Walking in the Rain
text: Helping a reader with a reluctant pet.

headline: Alec Baldwin Seeks to Avoid Liability in Fatal ‘Rust’ Shooting
text: Alec Baldwin gave his most detailed account yet of fatally shooting a cinematographer on the set of the film “Rust” last year in an arbitration demand that his lawyers filed Friday against his fellow producers, claiming that his contract protected him from financial responsibility in her death and seeking coverage of his legal fees.

headline: Wolves Returned to California. So Did ‘Crazy’ Rumors.
text: Kent Laudon, a wolf biologist with the California Department of Fish and Wildlife, woke up one morning last year to a flurry of text messages from a rancher in the state’s northernmost county. He was asking about a post with wildly specific details spreading across Facebook that urged people to find a red truck that was transporting breeding wolves along Route 97 into Siskiyou County, Calif. Mr. Laudon was not surprised. This wasn’t the first post of its kind, and it wouldn’t be the last.

headline: What to Cook This Weekend
text: Good morning. It’s getting toward ice-out season in some parts of the country, everything melting, making way for buds and flowers. It’s not pretty. (In Vermont, they call it mud season. Maine, too. In Alaska, it’s breakup.) Everything’s dirty, everything’s wet. But that little softness in the air? Those pale green shoots in the wrecked grass at the park? They are promise of a lovely season to come, even if the act of writing those words will no doubt bring one last vicious snowstorm to my door.

headline: Roman Abramovich and the End of Soccer’s Oligarch Era
text: There were, over the years, three stories that explained how Roman Abramovich washed ashore at Chelsea. Each one, now, serves as a kind of time capsule, a carbon-dated relic from a specific period, capturing in amber each stage of our understanding of what, precisely, soccer has become.

headline: Five International Movies to Stream Now
text: A narrative feature by the Mexican comedian Gabriel Nuncio, “This Is Not a Comedy” is a strange and audacious concoction of kooky, funny and sad. Gabriel, playing himself, is a down-and-out stand-up comedian in Mexico City with dreams of producing his first screenplay, about a female astronaut who goes to Mars. The story seems inspired by Gabriel’s girlfriend, the eccentric Leyre (Cassandra Ciangherotti), who talks to plants and believes that aliens will arrive soon to take her away. Her bright-eyed curiosity can’t seem to penetrate the cynical, broke-as-hell Gabriel, who is a repeat victim of Murphy’s law: In a running gag, he keeps forgetting his keys and has to have a locksmith break him into his apartment.

headline: U.S. and Allies Move to Further Isolate Russia From Global Economy
text: WASHINGTON — President Biden and other Western leaders moved on Friday to further isolate Russia from the global trading system, saying they would strip the country of normal trade relations and take other steps to sever its links to the world economy in response to President Vladimir V. Putin’s invasion of Ukraine.

headline: Disabled Chinese Fight for Equal Rights Despite Paralympic Glory
text: BEIJING — As Li Xiang strapped himself into a seat mounted atop a single ski and raced down the snowy slope, he reveled in the feeling of freedom that had become all too rare after a car accident required him to use a wheelchair as a child.

headline: The Best of Late Night This Week 🌙
text: The late-night hosts devoted this week to Russia’s invasion of Ukraine and its wider effects, including skyrocketing gas prices in the United States. Here’s what they had to say.

headline: Hong Kong’s overwhelmed hospitals are keeping the dead in wards with Covid patients.
text: It’s an image that shocked many: bodies of the dead piled up next to Covid patients.

headline: What’s in Our Queue? Gayle and More
text: I'm The Times's film editor. Here are five things I've been watching, reading and listening to.

headline: ‘My Cousin Vinny’ at 30: An Unlikely Oscar Winner
text: When the culture-clash courtroom comedy “My Cousin Vinny” landed in theaters on March 13, 1992, the critical response was mostly positive. The Times’s Vincent Canby found it “inventive and enjoyable,” The Los Angeles Times’s Peter Rainer called it “often funny” and The Hollywood Reporter deemed it “a terrific variation on the fish-out-of-water/man-from-Mars story formula.”

headline: Bitcoin Was Made for This Moment. So Why Isn’t It Booming?
text: For years, Bitcoin buffs who were questioned by skeptics about the value of the cryptocurrency would respond by saying: just wait.

headline: A growing force in the climate movement: Moms
text: Many of you write to us and tell us about your feelings of powerlessness in the face of a global climate catastrophe. That sentiment is giving rise to a small but potentially potent force in the climate movement: moms, who have been catapulted into action by the hazards facing their children.

headline: ‘This Is Everyone’s Culture’: Ukraine’s Architectural Treasures Face Destruction
text: Russia’s invasion of Ukraine brought searing images of human tragedy to witnesses around the world: thousands of civilians killed and injured; broken families, as mothers and children leave in search of refuge while fathers and other men stay behind to defend their country; and millions of refugees having already fled to neighboring countries, after just two weeks of war.

headline: Legislators Find Way to Let U.C. Berkeley Increase Its Enrollment
text: Scrambling to short-circuit a court-ordered enrollment freeze at the University of California, Berkeley, state legislators on Friday unveiled a proposed change to a landmark environmental law that would let the university admit students at its previously planned level despite a lawsuit charging that its growth is polluting the city.

headline: Oscars Rewind: When Rita Moreno Made History and Thanked No One
text: It was the night that cemented her place in history, and Rita Moreno almost skipped it.

headline: Discovery’s shareholders approve a merger with WarnerMedia.
text: Discovery’s shareholders approved its coming merger with WarnerMedia on Friday, setting the stage for the two companies to combine in a matter of weeks.

headline: Megan Thee Stallion and Dua Lipa’s Sultry Team-Up, and 10 More New Songs
text: Every Friday, pop critics for The New York Times weigh in on the week’s most notable new songs and videos. Just want the music? Listen to the Playlist on Spotify here (or find our profile: nytimes). Like what you hear? Let us know at theplaylist@nytimes.com and sign up for our Louder newsletter, a once-a-week blast of our pop music coverage.

headline: Theory About U.S.-Funded Bioweapons Labs in Ukraine Is Unfounded
text: WASHINGTON — Prominent social media users and conservative voices have amplified a baseless theory promoted by Russian state media accusing the United States of funding biological weapons laboratories in Ukraine.

headline: So Much Suffering in the Ukraine War

headline: Meet the East Coast’s New Spider Friend 🕷
text: An invasive spider the size of a human palm could soon spread from Georgia throughout the East Coast.

headline: Over Ukraine, Lumbering Turkish-Made Drones Are an Ominous Sign for Russia
text: Ukraine’s most sophisticated attack drone is about as stealthy as a crop duster: slow, low-flying and completely defenseless. So when the Russian invasion began, many experts expected the few drones that the Ukrainian forces managed to get off the ground would be shot down in hours.

headline: Roman Abramovich’s Fortune Bought Him Good Will, and Made Him a Target
text: As Russian troops massed near the border with Ukraine last month, the American ambassador to Israel received an appeal on behalf of Roman Abramovich, the most visible of the billionaires linked to President Vladimir V. Putin.

headline: Wonking Out: Lies, Damned Lies and Gasoline Prices
text: Let me offer two theories about recent events. You tell me which you find more credible.

headline: How We Verify Our Reporting on the Ukraine War
text: The Times has deployed dozens of reporters, photographers, videographers, audio journalists, writers and others to Ukraine and the countries bordering it to deliver real-time, independent, in-depth coverage of the conflict and its reverberations across the region. Times journalists are witnessing events on the ground as they unfold, reporting from battlefields, hospitals, improvised bomb shelters and contested cities.

headline: ‘Encanto’ May Be Accurate, but Can It Carry a Whole Country?
text: “Encanto” wasn’t always set in Colombia.

headline: Skewering the Anxious Young Things
text: LONDON — Seven years ago, Tom Stourton, 35, received a wedding invitation from two college friends. He was surprised, having drifted apart from the couple. But he attended the event, arriving hung over and sleep deprived from another party the night before.

headline: The Weekender
text: Lao cooks celebrate their cuisine. Also in this edition: Al Pacino on 50 years of ‘The Godfather’ and the Staten Island house where Black history lives.

headline: Harris Tells Americans They Will Have to Pay More for Gas to Punish Russia
text: BUCHAREST — Vice President Kamala Harris said Friday that Americans will have to bear the burden of higher gas prices, but insisted that it was a cost worth paying to punish Russia for waging war on Ukraine.

headline: Review: At Carnegie, Going Beyond the Rapid-Fire Vivaldi
text: Slow, serene, more floating than furious: A Vivaldi concert at Weill Recital Hall on Thursday began in decidedly un-Vivaldian style.

headline: Harry Truman: The Everyman President
text: THE TRIALS OF HARRY S. TRUMANThe Extraordinary Presidency of an Ordinary Man, 1945-1953

headline: These Garlic Noodles Are Magic
text: There is good weeknight cooking, and then there is great weeknight cooking: streamlined and smart, leveraging a few magic ingredients and a great technique to produce maximal flavor in minimal time. This week we’ve got a superb example in J. Kenji López-Alt’s noodles, which are made with a garlic-butter sauce and a powerful umami triumvirate — oyster sauce, fish sauce and soy sauce. It’s a recipe from his new book, “The Wok,” that’s based on a dish from the San Francisco Vietnamese restaurant Thanh Long.

headline: At Indian Wells, Ukrainian Tennis Stars Take Their Fight to the Court
text: INDIAN WELLS, Calif. — The Ukrainian teenager Marta Kostyuk and the Belgian veteran Maryna Zanevska played for more than three hours in the sun and a swirling wind.

headline: Manhattan’s Chinese Street Signs Are Disappearing
text: The arrival, expansion and disappearance of these bilingual street signs have traced the ebb and flow of Chinese immigration in New York’s oldest Chinatown.

headline: The Case for Induction Cooking
text: Robert Osborne grew anxious about dinner when his Brooklyn co-op board put the kibosh on a plan to move a gas line for his kitchen renovation. How could Mr. Osborne, a math teacher, cook his favorite dishes like skillet chicken with caramelized mushrooms and onions if he couldn’t do it over the classic blue-orange blaze of a gas stove?

headline: Love Letter: What an Illness Reveals
text: When he was 17 and in his second year of university, Chisom Peter Job collapsed while sweeping the floor. He was then diagnosed with coronary heart disease and had to move back home.

headline: Yes, You Can Make Salmon on the Stovetop Without the Smell
text: There’s a line of shops on a tree-lined road in Dublin, with O’Briens Wine in the center, a butcher and grocer on either side and a minimart at the far end. Taken together, they have most everything you would need to prepare meals. I know, because I dragged my daughter into each store and examined every aisle.

headline: The global supply chain’s pandemic recovery is another casualty of Russia’s invasion of Ukraine.
text: Just as the global economy was on track to emerge from the coronavirus pandemic, Russia’s invasion of Ukraine and global sanctions against Moscow are rippling through logistics and supply chains, creating bottlenecks in the transport of goods and commodities and threatening fresh economic pain for countries and businesses near the conflict zone.

headline: Saudi Blogger, Jailed and Flogged for Liberal Views, Is Freed From Prison
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — A Saudi blogger who was flogged in a public square after expressing liberal views on the internet and whose case became a lightning rod for international criticism of the kingdom’s intolerance for dissent was released from prison on Friday, his wife and son wrote on Twitter.

headline: Russian Sieges of Ukrainian Cities Provoke Bitter Recollections for Syrians
text: Huda Khayti endured years of deprivation under siege by Syrian government forces in a rebel-held Damascus suburb. The thing she says she remembers most is the screams of her neighbors’ hungry children in the middle of the night.

headline: Deshaun Watson Won’t Face Criminal Charges in Houston Cases, Grand Jury Decides
text: HOUSTON — Deshaun Watson, the 26-year-old N.F.L. quarterback who has been accused by two dozen women of sexual misconduct during massage appointments, will not be criminally charged in Houston, a grand jury decided Friday.

headline: Rusty Mae Moore, Transgender Educator and Activist, Dies at 80
text: Rusty Mae Moore, a transgender educator and activist who housed numerous transgender people in the 1990s and 2000s in her Brooklyn home, a de facto shelter that became known as Transy House, died on Feb. 23 at her home in Pine Hill, N.Y., in the Catskills. She was 80.

headline: San Francisco Mayor Replaces Ousted School Board Members
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Three weeks after a decisive vote to recall members of the San Francisco school board, the city’s mayor filled the vacated positions on Friday with a slate of parents who she said would tend to the “urgent needs” of the city’s public school students.

headline: Woodblock Prints and Hindu Gods at Asia Week New York
text: For more than a decade, before the pandemic, collectors and private dealers of Asian antiquities would converge in New York every spring for annual auctions at half a dozen houses including Bonham’s, Christie’s and Sotheby’s. Many out-of-town dealers would set up shows of their own in hotels or partner galleries, while hometown galleries and museums mounted special exhibitions for the occasion.

headline: Texas Court Halts Abuse Inquiries Into Parents of Transgender Children
text: HOUSTON — Investigations of parents with transgender children for possible child abuse were temporarily halted across Texas on Friday after a state court ruled that the policy, ordered last month by Gov. Greg Abbott, had been improperly adopted and violated the State Constitution.

text: The most recent Disney megahit doesn't work like the usual Disney megahit.

text: "It’s kind of like when it’s raining and the weather is crazy outside, but it feels peaceful."
