text: Featuring music from Mary J. Blige, Olivia Rodrigo, Beach House, Mitski and more.

headline: With Trump in Her State, Haley Finds Some Political Distance (Gently)
text: WASHINGTON — Rumors were swirling in South Carolina early this February that Donald J. Trump would try to tear down a Republican congresswoman who had incurred his wrath.

headline: Indexes, Soaring Imaginations and Other Letters to the Editor
text: To the Editor:

headline: Fashion Week Style: Well Framed
text: Throughout fashion month, which concluded this week in Paris, the photographer Simbarashe Cha was out on the sidewalks searching for moments of personal style. Everywhere he went, eyewear in an endless variety of shapes and colors was on display. Here are some of the best frames he saw in four cities.

headline: Bye Bye Iowa? Democrats to Debate Changes to Primary Calendar
text: For years, Democrats in Iowa and New Hampshire have battled criticism from others in the party who argued that the two states are not racially diverse enough to kick off the Democratic nomination process.

headline: Disney Can’t Hide From Politics
text: The Walt Disney Company has a big problem. It wants to be loved by everybody: Massachusetts liberals and Mississippi conservatives, Muslims in Saudi Arabia and atheists in China. It therefore prefers to minimize the number of times it takes stands on hot-button social issues.

headline: Ukrainian Isn’t ‘Little Russian’ and Black English Isn’t Broken
text: It was long ago common for Russians to regard Ukrainian as just a dialect of Russian. “Little Russian,” it was called. Writing for The Conversation this week, Florida International University’s Phillip Carter said, “If you ask some Russian nationalists, Ukrainian isn’t a language at all,” noting that in the 1863 Valuev Circular, Pyotr Valuev, Russia’s interior minister, decreed that a separate Ukrainian language did not exist.

headline: President Zelensky Makes His Case for Ukraine to the Russian People
text: The thing about the videos from the war in Ukraine in 2014 was that there were very few war videos. It was, at least at first, a small-arms war. Fighting, when it erupted, happened on city streets. As soon as shots were fired, whoever was making the video would put away the phone and run.

headline: Facebook’s Parent Company Will Make Employees Do Their Own Laundry
text: The salad days of Facebook’s lavish employee perks may be coming to an end.

headline: The Price of Putin’s Belligerence
text: As his ruthless invasion continues, Vladimir Putin is trying to break Ukraine by demolishing its cities and brutalizing its people. Each day brings fresh horrors. A family killed while crossing a bridge to safety. Fathers and children touching hands and parting. A maternity hospital blasted into pieces in Mariupol, where roughly half a million people are under siege.

headline: Ukraine War Gives Freight Firm a New Purpose: ‘I’m Fighting This Way’
text: PORT READING, N.J. — A blue dot on a box means nonperishable food, ready for shipping. A red dot means first-aid items for hospitals still standing. A green dot means supplies for Ukrainians taking up arms: boots and kneepads, socks and gloves, thermal underwear and camouflage-patterned clothing.

headline: U.S. Official Ends Sentence of Terrorist Who Was Tortured by C.I.A.
text: GUANTÁNAMO BAY, Cuba — A confessed courier for Al Qaeda whose tale of torture by the C.I.A. disgusted a U.S. military jury has completed his prison sentence, the Pentagon announced Friday. Now U.S. diplomats have to find a place for him to go.

headline: ‘We Live in a Different World Now’: Dispatch From a Changed Germany
text: BERLIN — Nils Schmid, a member of Germany’s Parliament and a foreign policy spokesman for the Social Democratic Party, was explaining to me what a minor role the military plays in his country’s politics.

headline: Parents Relying on Ukraine Surrogates Desperately Seek Their Newborns
text: On the day Russia invaded Ukraine, Max and his wife drove from their home in Germany to Poland, and then crossed the border into Ukraine. With fear, they moved in the opposite direction of the long line of cars that intended to flee the country and that was snarling the roads for miles.

headline: Britain’s High Court rules against a virus-related ban on a memorial vigil in London last year.
text: LONDON — The London police violated the human rights of four organizers in banning a March 2021 vigil for a woman who was killed by a police officer, the British High Court ruled on Friday. The police had cited coronavirus restrictions in banning the vigil.

headline: Jussie Smollett, Once an ‘Empire’ Star, Is Now in the Cook County Jail
text: It was an extraordinary ending to an unusual hearing.

headline: The New Captain of the Endurance Shipwreck Is an Anemone
text: Huw Griffiths, a marine bio-geographer at the British Antarctic Survey, was eating pancakes when news broke that the wreck of the Endurance — the famed ship helmed by Ernest Shackleton that sank in an expedition in 1915 — had been discovered.

headline: A Ketamine Clinic Treads the Line Between Health Care and a ‘Spa Day for Your Brain’
text: The décor of the Nushama Psychedelic Wellness Clinic was designed to look like bliss. “It doesn’t feel like a hospital or a clinic, but more like a journey,” said Jay Godfrey, the former fashion designer who co-founded the space with Richard Meloff, a lawyer turned cannabis entrepreneur.

headline: Burberry’s Alternate Fashion Reality
text: LONDON — Call it London Fashion Lunchtime.

headline: What Do I Do With All My Old Ties?
text: I imagine there is an ocean of men with the same problem: a tie rack full of ties and nowhere to wear them.

headline: Crème de Cassis for the 21st Century
text: Eaten fresh, black currants are tart and herbaceous. They pop with an earthy funk, playing musty and acidic on the tongue. When crushed, macerated in high-proof neutral alcohol and sweetened with sugar, the astringent fruit becomes a rich, deep red liqueur with a languid pour. A specialty of the Burgundy region of France (cassis translates to “black currant” in French), crème de cassis has been produced commercially since 1841.

headline: ‘Stealth’ Omicron Is Stealthy No More: What’s Known About the BA.2 Variant
text: As the Omicron coronavirus surge subsides, researchers are keeping an eye on a highly transmissible subvariant known as BA.2. Many epidemiologists suspect that it may reverse the decline of cases in the United States, but doubt that it will cause a large new spike.

headline: An Educator Read ‘I Need a New Butt!’ to Children. Then He Was Fired.
text: It was Read Across America week, and the second graders in the Hinds County School District in Mississippi were waiting for an administrator to read to them.

headline: The U.S. and the E.U., aiming to punish oligarchs, ban luxury exports to Russia.
text: Hermès scarves, Harry Winston jewels, Feadship yachts, Mercedes cars, Cognac and Champagne — none of these public badges of achievement and culture will be available to oligarchs in Russia any more.

headline: Court Declares Man Wrongfully Imprisoned for 45 Years
text: For decades, Isaiah Andrews has maintained his innocence in the 1974 murder of his wife, unaware that the key to his exoneration was buried in the archives of the Cleveland Division of Police.

headline: Fall Back? Spring Ahead? How About Neither, Experts Say.
text: On Sunday, most people in the United States “sprung” their clocks forward by one hour, heralding the end of standard time (with its brighter mornings and darker evenings) and the beginning of daylight saving time.

headline: A Rare Rainout Suspends Players Championship With Three Tied for Lead
text: PONTE VEDRA BEACH, Fla. — This year’s Players Championship, a signature event of the PGA Tour, will take an extra day to complete after torrential rains on Friday in northern Florida suspended play for a second consecutive day. Golfers endured Friday’s foul weather for only a few soggy hours at the T.P.C. Sawgrass golf course, one day after the first round was twice interrupted by rain delays and never completed.

headline: 2 Dead After Driver Crashes Outside a Restaurant in Washington, D.C.
text: An older driver lost control of his vehicle and crashed into an outdoor seating area at a busy restaurant in Washington, D.C., at lunchtime on Friday, killing two women and leaving three other people with life-threatening injuries, the authorities said.

headline: How People First Arrived in the Americas
text: Scholars have long believed that the first Americans arrived via land bridge some 13,000 years ago, when retreating glaciers created an inland corridor from Siberia. Jennifer Raff, an anthropological geneticist at the University of Kansas, tells a different story in “Origin.” According to Raff, the path to the Americas was coastal rather than inland, and what we’ve thought of as a bridge was a homeland inhabited for millenniums. Raff talks about the book on this week’s podcast.

headline: Reclaiming time lost to Covid
text: Two years ago today, the World Health Organization declared the Covid-19 outbreak a global pandemic. A week before that, this newsletter was born. Since then, we’ve been on a journey together — braving waves of infections, experiencing sickness and loss, mastering the art of protecting ourselves, and continuously learning about a wily virus that seemed to surprise experts at every turn.

headline: More Cities Bombarded
text: Good evening. This is your Russia-Ukraine War Briefing, a weeknight guide to the latest news and analysis about the conflict.

headline: How a Line of Russian Tanks Became an Inviting Target for Ukrainians
text: BROVARY, Ukraine — The column of Russian tanks rumbled along a main highway to the east of Kyiv, between two rows of houses in a small town — a vulnerable target.

headline: Bruce Duffy, Hailed for His Ambitious First Novel, Dies at 70
text: Bruce Duffy, an ambitious, inventive writer whose debut novel, “The World as I Found It” — with its improbable leading man, the Austrian philosopher Ludwig Wittgenstein — received rapturous reviews but nevertheless failed to make him a lasting literary star, died on Feb. 10 in hospice care in Rockville, Md. He was 70.

headline: U.S. Officials Say Superyacht Could be Putin’s
text: WASHINGTON — American officials are examining the ownership of a $700 million superyacht currently in a dry dock at an Italian seacoast town, and believe it could be associated with President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia, according to multiple people briefed on the information.

headline: The far right complains after the search engine DuckDuckGo vows to limit Russian propaganda.
text: Far-right influencers have often encouraged people to use the small privacy-focused search engine DuckDuckGo instead of Google, saying that the giant search engine censored conservative ideas.

headline: New ‘Deltacron’ Variant Is Rare and Similar to Omicron, Experts Say
text: In recent days, scientists have reported that a hybrid of the Omicron and Delta coronavirus variants has been popping up in several countries in Europe. Here’s what is known so far about the hybrid, which has picked up the Frankensteinian nicknames of Deltamicron or Deltacron.

headline: Your Friday Evening Briefing
text: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Slowed on the Battlefield, Russia Widens Bombardment of Ukrainian Cities
text: The Russian military struck Ukrainian cities far from the main battle lines on Friday, pressing its strategy of bombing Ukraine into submission as the country plunged deeper into misery and privation more than two weeks into the war.

headline: What to Know About Cryptocurrency and Taxes
text: Many people began buying crypto last year. They may not realize that, in some cases, they owe taxes on it.

headline: For M.L.B. and the Union, a Relationship in Need of Repair
text: After the leadership of the Major League Baseball players’ union voted, 26-12, to approve a new labor deal on Thursday afternoon — following years of building mistrust of management and months of tense negotiating — M.L.B.’s commissioner, Rob Manfred, picked up the phone.

headline: Johnny Grier, N.F.L.’s First Black Referee, Dies at 74
text: Johnny Grier, who became the first Black referee in the National Football League in 1988 and remained in that position, the top one in an officiating crew, for 16 years, died on Tuesday in Pasadena, Md. He was 74.

headline: With a lot of the world yet to be vaccinated, protesters demand that the technology be shared.
text: Scattered demonstrations around the globe on Friday seeking to waive intellectual property rights for Covid vaccines punctuated the second anniversary of the World Health Organization’s declaring the contagion a pandemic.

headline: Republicans Sense an Opportunity in Nevada’s Restless Latino Voters
text: When Senator Catherine Cortez Masto and her allies unveiled their first paid ads of the 2022 election cycle, the Nevada Democrat’s intended audience was clear: the state’s quarter-of-a-million Latino voters, a critical swing vote.

headline: Until recently it was the ‘stealth’ Omicron: Here’s what we know about the BA.2 variant.
text: As the Omicron coronavirus surge subsides, researchers are keeping an eye on a highly transmissible subvariant known as BA.2. Although it doesn’t appear to have the capacity to drive a large new wave of infections, the variant could potentially slow the current decline of Covid cases and make treatments more difficult.

headline: Officer Who Killed Ma’Khia Bryant Will Not Face Charges
text: A grand jury has voted to bring no charges against the white police officer who shot and killed Ma’Khia Bryant, a 16-year-old Black girl, as she swung a knife at a woman during a raucous dispute last year in the front yard of her foster home in Ohio.

headline: Afghan Embassy, Now Out of Money, Will Shut Down, U.S. Says
text: WASHINGTON — Without the backing of a recognized government or money to keep the lights on, Afghanistan’s embassy to the United States is shutting down, State Department officials said on Friday.

headline: Brittney Griner’s Circle Turns to a Common Strategy: Silence
text: The detention of the W.N.B.A. star Brittney Griner in Russia on drug charges has left her supporters searching for a road map to a resolution in what could be an especially dangerous situation during the war in Ukraine.

headline: Texas Supreme Court Shuts Down Final Challenge to Abortion Law
text: The Texas Supreme Court on Friday effectively shut down a federal challenge to the state’s novel and controversial ban on abortion after about six weeks of pregnancy, closing off what abortion rights advocates said was their last, narrow path to blocking the new law.

headline: Are We Facing Nuclear War?
text: From “The Daily” newsletter: One big idea on the news, from the team that brings you “The Daily” podcast. You can sign up for the newsletter here.

headline: M.L.B. Nears Deal With Another Streaming Service to Carry Some Games Exclusively
text: Ready to watch Major League Baseball before lunch? That will be an option if NBCUniversal completes a deal with the league to carry 18 games on its Peacock streaming service, some starting as early as 11:30 a.m. Eastern time and others just after noon, a person with knowledge of the deal said on Friday.

headline: Fed officials meet to set rates, and new data on retail sales: the week ahead in business.
Queen Elizabeth is skipping next week’s Commonwealth Day service.
text: Buckingham Palace said on Friday that Queen Elizabeth II, who recently recovered from Covid-19, will not attend a Commonwealth Day service at Westminster Abbey next week — in what would have been her first major public engagement in weeks.

headline: West Point Cadets Overdose During Spring Break in Florida, Officials Say
text: Several West Point cadets were among six young men on spring break who overdosed this week on what was believed to be cocaine laced with fentanyl at a rental home in Wilton Manors, Fla., officials said Friday.

headline: Mentally Worn Out
text: SATURDAY PUZZLE — It has been more than three and a half years since we’ve solved a Natan Last puzzle on a Saturday, which is far too long. This constructor is deservedly a favorite among solvers, and this puzzle shouldn’t disappoint — a lot of nimble wordplay, interesting trivia and not a single dud or misstep that I can see.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Putin Oligarch Finds Himself Pariah in West’s Playgrounds
text: “The blood of the Ukrainian people is on their hands. They should hang their heads in shame.”

headline: Corrections: March 12, 2022
text: An article on Friday about a collective bargaining agreement between Major League Baseball’s club owners and its players’ union misstated the amount that the M.L.B.’s luxury tax threshold will increase to in 2026. It is $244 million, not $242 million.

headline: China dismisses two mayors and Shanghai closes schools as an outbreak spreads further.
text: BEIJING — Two mayors have been dismissed in northeastern China, and Shanghai has closed its school system and shifted to online instruction, as a coronavirus outbreak in mainland China gathers speed.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
text: SATURDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.

headline: Shaming Apple and Texting Musk, a Ukraine Minister Uses Novel War Tactics
text: After war began last month, President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine turned to Mykhailo Fedorov, a vice prime minister, for a key role.

headline: Paris Fashion Week: Standing Out in the Crowds
text: There’s just nothing like photographing people in Paris, but over the past two years the scene has changed and evolved as the fashion shows stumbled along through each pandemic wave. Now, the streets are full again. Camera technology allows novices to take exceptional photos. Most notably, the level of style from fans outside the shows has been so elevated, it would be foolish for the photographers who usually train their lenses on fashion editors and influencers who wear heritage brands to ignore them. It brings a renewed excitement, reminiscent of the old days when someone might be discovered shopping at a mall — a thrill like the kind one experiences when unearthing a gem at a thrift store.

headline: India Accidentally Fires a Missile at Pakistan. Calm Ensues.
text: JAIPUR, India — One nuclear-armed state fired a cruise missile at another nuclear-armed state this week. They were not at war, and it did not start one.

headline: American Voters Now View Ukraine as Favorably as France, Germany and Japan
text: In a new  survey, 81 percent of Americans say Ukraine is either friendly or an ally, a figure that rivals or  exceeds that of many longtime U.S. allies.

headline: The Land of the Ice and Snow
text: EXTREME NORTH: A Cultural HistoryBy Bernd Brunner Translated by Jefferson Chase

headline: How Much Real Money Can You Make From Virtual Art?
text: Late on a Friday last spring, Izzy Pollak decided to buy two Bored Ape NFTs, which — as a reminder for the many people thinking, Yeah, but I still don’t know what an NFT is — means he bought unique, digital images (in this case, of apes).

headline: Saving Each Other’s Lives, Quite Literally
text: Brian Gari has a background in theater, but nothing could prepare him for the drama of his first years of marriage to Jeanne Cathcart.

headline: First Comes Marriage, Then Comes Love
text: “Marriage isn’t a word — it’s a sentence.” That famous quip is especially true in romance novels, where marriage is often a starting point rather than an end goal. This month we look at three new romances in which a wedding is not a bow tied on at the finish, but a tether pulling characters through the plot.

headline: For Italy’s Sled Hockey Team, ‘This One Means More’
text: BEIJING — There are no medals for fifth place in the Paralympic sled hockey tournament. But judging by the scenes of exultation and joy on the ice at China’s National Indoor Stadium on Friday, the Italian national team will cope just fine without them.

headline: That Russian Business You’re Boycotting Isn’t Actually Russian
text: They poured the liquid out — blueberry-flavored, orange-flavored and the original, face-puckering unflavored version — tweeting #DumpRussianVodka and, at gay bars across the country, made do with Absolut and soda instead.

headline: Hundreds of Planes Are Stranded in Russia. They May Never Be Recovered.
text: Hope has faded quickly for a handful of Western companies eager to recover planes leased to airlines in Russia, with the authorities there intent on keeping foreign-registered aircraft within the country and President Vladimir V. Putin openly discussing nationalizing the assets of foreign businesses.

headline: An Author Wrote About Her Sister’s Murder. It Led to a Breakthrough.
text: It took Cristina Rivera Garza 30 years to write the story of her sister’s unsolved murder.

headline: House Democrats Push Biden to Build a Better Midterm Message
text: WASHINGTON — After offering her customary lavish praise of President Biden, House Speaker Nancy Pelosi got to the business at hand at a White House meeting last month on the midterm elections.

headline: After 2 Years of Pandemic Life, Turn Toward Normalcy Is a Shake-Up
text: It was two years ago that the World Health Organization declared Covid-19 a pandemic, and after nearly one million deaths across the United States, the virus is far from gone. Rates of new infections, while improving, are still higher now than the beginning of last summer.

headline: What It Was Like to Work for Russian State Television
text: For eight years, Lee Camp hosted a weekly show on RT America that aimed to satirize American politics, finding punchlines in subjects like sanctions against Afghanistan and student debt forgiveness. That ended unceremoniously on March 3, a week after Russian airstrikes began in Ukraine, when the Russian-state-funded network suddenly shut down.

headline: Chaos of War in Ukraine Could Fuel New Covid Surge, Doctors Say
text: LVIV, Ukraine — The last thing on anybody’s mind these days in Ukraine seems to be Covid.

headline: Russian Scientists Face Isolation Following Invasion of Ukraine
text: One of the glories of international scientific collaborations, besides sharing costs and brainpower, is the building of personal relationships that transcend individual cultures, traditions and political regimes.

headline: Maluma, Fashion Chameleon
text: A few days after a January snowstorm, Juan Luis Londoño Arias, the 28-year-old Colombian pop star who performs as Maluma, entered a Midtown Manhattan office building near the Macy’s flagship store. Wearing a tie-dyed, periwinkle, denim jacket and pants, he’d somehow managed to keep his chunky-soled white leather Prada boots pristine, despite the rivers of slush on the sidewalks. Like magic, shortly after he showed up, the sun broke through the overcast sky.

headline: He Spent Decades Protecting Buffalo. A Microscopic Invader Threatens That Work.
text: BLACKFOOT, S.D. — On the ice-glazed banks of the Missouri River, coyotes chewed through the hide of a buffalo that had recently died from disease. In a corral up the hill, more than 20 orphaned buffalo calves crowded together in the cold with no mother to protect them. Down in the pasture, a few animals stood apart from the others, coughing violently, clouds of their breath hanging in the winter air.

headline: Pandemic Fears Give Way to a Rush for Bomb Shelters
text: BAGNOLO SAN VITO, Italy — Across a footbridge from a busy shopping outlet surrounded by verdant fields in northern Italy, workers in a nondescript warehouse are preparing for a nuclear attack, its radioactive fallout and the end of the world as we know it.

headline: Arctic Security Concerns Resurface in Canada’s Territories Amid Russian War
text: For the better part of next week, residents in Canada’s Northwest Territories may see a greater military presence and aircraft whirring about.

headline: Bilingual Signs Are Disappearing in Chinatown. We Investigated.
text: Aaron Reiss, a freelance multimedia journalist covering immigrant communities in New York City, and Denise Lu, a graphics editor at The Times, teamed up for an article that examines bilingual signs in Manhattan’s Chinatown. Together, they shared how the article came together.

headline: Here are the latest developments in Ukraine.
text: LVIV, Ukraine — The war in Ukraine expanded significantly on Sunday as Russian warplanes struck a military base near the Polish border where foreign fighters including Americans were being trained. At least nine people were killed and 57 wounded, officials said.

headline: Pandemic Playlists
text: To get through the pandemic, the writer Hanif Abdurraqib has relied on “sad bangers”: “songs whose lyrics of grief, anxiety, yearning or some other mild or great darkness are washed over with an upbeat tune, or a chorus so infectious that it can weave its way into your brain without your brain taking stock of whatever emotional damage it carries with it.” Bruce Springsteen’s “Hungry Heart” is a sad banger, he writes in The Times Magazine’s annual music issue. So are Robyn’s “Dancing on My Own” and Lil Nas X’s “Lost in the Citadel.”

headline: Yarn, Introspection and Pancakes
text: Hello, readers.

headline: ‘The Bond King’ Traces the Arc of a Pioneering Investor
text: The DealBook newsletter delves into a single topic or theme every weekend, providing reporting and analysis that offers a better understanding of an important issue in business. If you don’t already receive the daily newsletter, sign up here.

headline: Parents, What Would Make Your Lives Better?
text: On this day two years ago, I remember gripping my younger daughter’s hand especially tight on the way to her preschool. We were almost at the front door when I felt my phone buzz with an email from the school: A parent in the community had been exposed to the coronavirus, and “out of an abundance of caution we recommend that you keep your child home if possible.”

headline: McDonald’s Ice Cream Woes Have Inspired Memes, Mockery and Now, a Federal Lawsuit
text: It’s a perennial lament of McDonald’s loyalists: Why are the ice cream machines always down?

headline: Donald Pinkel, Who Developed a Cure for Childhood Leukemia, Dies at 95
text: Dr. Donald Pinkel, a pediatrician who, starting in the early 1960s, developed an aggressive treatment for childhood leukemia that transformed the disease from a virtual death sentence to one that almost every patient survives, died on Wednesday at his home in San Luis Obispo, Calif. He was 95.

headline: The Pros and Cons of Buying a Tenant-Occupied Apartment
text: Q: We are considering buying a tenant-occupied apartment in a condo. The tenant has lived there since August 2019, and the market-rate lease will expire in four months. The seller’s agent said they could deliver the apartment vacant, but that we’d have more leverage on the sale price if we kept the tenant. We visited the apartment and the tenant has kept everything clean and in good shape. We’re not in a rush to occupy the apartment and it would be nice to have some income in the interim. What are the pitfalls we should be aware of before we make this decision?

headline: How to Watch the Critics Choice Awards 2022: Date, Time and Streaming
text: Follow live coverage of the 2022 Critics Choice Awards.

headline: Booster shot data from New York City shows major disparities by race and neighborhood.
text: Much like the rest of the United States, New York City has struggled to convince some groups of residents to get a booster shot of the coronavirus vaccine. But new data released by the city on Wednesday shows wide disparities among who in the city is getting a third dose.

headline: France Cares About Green Causes, but Not Its Green Party
text: MONTPELLIER, France — Yannick Jadot, the candidate for the French Green Party in April’s presidential elections, walked through a small cheering crowd to a podium topped with banners featuring his face, as speakers blasted a version of “What a Wonderful World” by the punk rock singer Joey Ramone. The candidate bobbed his head to the rhythm.

headline: On Pacific Islands Covid Once Spared, an Outbreak Accentuates Inequality
text: NOUMÉA, New Caledonia — Festooned with hibiscus flowers and woven palm fronds, scores of guests gathered for a celebration during New Caledonia’s wedding season. The aroma of grilled fish and yams bathed in coconut milk wafted over the revelers on the island of Lifou, population 10,000.

headline: Zelensky Answers Hamlet
text: WASHINGTON — For actors, it is the most gripping, feared line ever written.

headline: One More Census Takeaway: The End of an Era of Counting the Nation?
text: WASHINGTON — Beyond the reports of undercounts and overcounts in population totals, there is another takeaway from the post-mortem of 2020 census data issued on Thursday: This could be the last census of its kind.

headline: Mask mandates were extended for U.S. transit, but dropped in many other settings: The week in Covid news.
text: In an aggressive step toward normalcy, public school students in New York City returned to mask-optional classrooms on Monday for the first time since the start of the pandemic.

headline: The Comfort of Sports During Difficult Times
text: As I sit writing in a quiet part of my apartment building, I can see two televisions. One is playing CNN. Jake Tapper is asking a reporter how victims of the opioid crisis confronted the Sackler family, which owns Purdue Pharma, at a hearing on Thursday. Earlier, the network focused on images from the war in Ukraine — bloodied victims of bombings, bodies buried in mass graves, buildings on fire.

headline: Can Public Health Be Saved?
text: This article is part of Times Opinion’s reflection on the two-year mark of the Covid pandemic. Read more in a note from Alexandra Sifferlin, Opinion’s health and science editor, in our Opinion Today newsletter.

headline: How to Wean Europe Off Russian Gas as Swiftly as Possible
text: Russia’s unprovoked invasion of Ukraine has pressed Europe to fundamentally rethink how it keeps its lights on and its industries powered. Steps that would have sounded crazy only a few weeks ago — burning more coal or scaling up government intervention in energy markets — are now urgently needed to stop financing Vladimir Putin’s war.

headline: Just How Liberal Is California? The Answer Matters to Democrats Everywhere.
text: LOS ANGELES — California is awash in money, with so many billions in surplus revenue that the state cannot enact programs fast enough. Democrats hold veto-proof majorities in the Legislature, and Gov. Gavin Newsom has a $25 million campaign war chest to fend off any token opposition in his re-election bid.

headline: Cancel Culture in 1832 Sounded Pretty Fierce
text: One important reason to study history as a social critic or political observer is that it can help you see continuities across time, the ways that certain social and political dynamics recapitulate themselves in various contexts and circumstances. Even as every particular instance of the thing is different, the fact of continuity helps an observer see that the phenomenon does not simply erupt out of the ether, but is the product of larger forces in the society.

headline: Ukraine War Ushers In ‘New Era’ for U.S. Abroad
text: WASHINGTON — The war in Ukraine has prompted the biggest rethinking of American foreign policy since the Sept. 11, 2001, attacks, infusing the United States with a new sense of mission and changing its strategic calculus with allies and adversaries alike.

headline: The Villages in Florida: Shangri-La or Shameful?
text: To the Editor:

headline: U.S. to Send Arms to Ukraine, as Russia Intensifies Campaign of Destruction
text: LVIV, Ukraine — Russian forces stepped up their campaign of bombardments aimed at devastating Ukraine’s cities and towns on Saturday, as the White House announced it was sending an additional $200 million in arms and equipment to help Ukraine, defying Moscow.

headline: Bringing Outsider Artists In
text: Sophia Cosmadopoulos and Anna Schechter, who run Summertime Gallery in East Williamsburg, Brooklyn, don’t write the press materials for their exhibitions. And when the women organize a show, they exercise little influence over the artwork on display, or even how the gallery looks. They are, by design, hands-off gallerists.

headline: Meet the Underdog of Senior Care
text: Felicia Biteranta was struggling when, five years ago, she enrolled in a PACE program operated by Lutheran Senior Life in Jersey City, N.J.

headline: With Bombings and a Funeral, the War Arrives in Ukraine’s West
text: LUTSK, Ukraine — Men in camouflage, hardened by battle, sniffled as a Ukrainian Orthodox choir sang the haunting funeral mass. One man put his arm around another as tears welled in his eyes.

headline: The White House approves $200 million in arms and equipment for Ukraine.
text: WASHINGTON — The White House has approved an additional $200 million in arms and equipment for Ukraine, administration officials said on Saturday, responding to urgent requests from President Volodymyr Zelensky for more aid to stave off the Russian invasion.

headline: In a Kyiv Basement, 19 Surrogate Babies Are Trapped by War but Kept Alive by Nannies
text: KYIV, Ukraine — Down a dusty stairwell, hidden from the shelling that has become the grim background noise of Ukraine’s capital, Ludmila Yashenko fusses with the babies. There are 19 of them, sleeping or cooing in neatly arranged cribs, fed regularly from tubs of baby formula.

headline: After Days of Uncertainty, a Ukrainian Soldier Is Laid to Rest
text: Senior Lt. Vasyl Vyshyvanyi was killed by Russian forces on March 3, but heavy combat kept the military from evacuating his body. Six days later, he was buried in his home village outside Lviv.

headline: Street battles hit a Kyiv suburb, some of the closest fighting to the capital yet.
text: IRPIN, Ukraine — In Irpin, just outside the capital city of Kyiv, Ukrainian and Russian soldiers were fighting a street-by-street battle on Saturday, turning what was a leafy suburb just two weeks ago into a suburban battleground.

headline: Bobbie Nelson, Longtime Pianist for Brother Willie, Dies at 91
text: Bobbie Nelson, the longtime piano player in her brother Willie’s band and a grounding influence in his life and music, died on Thursday in Austin, Texas. She was 91.

headline: How Ukrainian Paralympians Pushed Through Fear and Worry
text: BEIJING — With heavy hearts and unimaginable worry, athletes from the Ukrainian national Paralympic team arrived in China two weeks ago, seeking to win medals and draw attention to the plight of their country through their athletic achievement.

headline: The Ukraine War and the Retro-Future
text: Long before Vladimir Putin’s invasion of Ukraine, his aggressions were often met by the accusation — leveled by John Kerry and Angela Merkel, among others — that he’s a 19th-century figure in a 21st-century world. It’s a line that seemed intended to judge Putin guilty not just of wickedness but of anachronism, which is somehow more confounding to the modern mind.

headline: Florida’s ‘Don’t Say Gay’ Bill Will Hurt Teens Like Me
text: Last October, I attended a high school Halloween party. A group of guys from my school surrounded me and shouted homophobic slurs. One even threatened me with physical violence. When I broke down crying in class the next day, my teacher comforted me. She told me that she had gone through something similar when she was my age.

headline: The Russians Might Have Expected a Warm Welcome. Instead the Mayor Labeled Them ‘Occupiers.’
text: LVIV, Ukraine — Ivan Fyodorov, as his name suggests, is an ethnic Russian in a southern Ukrainian city where Russian is commonly spoken and where cultural and familial ties to the motherland run deep.

headline: Ron Miles, Understated Master of Jazz Cornet, Is Dead at 58
text: Ron Miles, whose gleaming, generously understated cornet playing made him one of the most rewarding bandleaders in contemporary jazz, if also one of its most easily overlooked, died on Tuesday at his home in Denver. He was 58.

headline: Police ID Suspect in Stabbing of MoMA Employees
text: A man who was denied entry to the Museum of Modern Art because his membership had been revoked jumped over the reception desk and stabbed two employees on Saturday afternoon, the police said.

headline: Scherzer’s Message as Camp Opens: ‘It’s Over. Let’s Just Play Baseball.’
text: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — Max Scherzer, the Mets’ new star pitcher, was perhaps the most prominent face of the players’ union’s fight with Major League Baseball’s club owners over a new labor contract.

headline: Body Language
text: SUNDAY PUZZLE — This is Christina Iverson and Katie Hale’s second clever Sunday collaboration; they’ve gone from audible to visual wordplay with this grid, whose theme reminds me of a large, organized variety puzzle.

headline: Yuriko, Keeper of Martha Graham’s Flame, Is Dead at 102
text: Yuriko Kikuchi, who under the single name Yuriko was a leading dancer in Martha Graham’s company from the 1940s to 1967 and then a keeper of Graham’s flame through her demanding teaching and outstanding revivals of early Graham works, died on Tuesday in Manhattan. She was 102.

headline: Traci Braxton, Television Personality and Singer, Dies at 50
text: Traci Braxton, a television personality and singer, died on Saturday. She was 50.

headline: L.S.U. Men’s Basketball Coach Fired After N.C.A.A. Alleges Violations
text: Louisiana State abruptly fired men’s basketball coach Will Wade on Saturday, less than a week after the school received a notice of allegations from the N.C.A.A. that accused Wade of five major rules violations, including making cash payments and job offers to help lure a recruit to the school.

headline: Oregon and Washington State, known for cautious Covid strategies, lift their statewide mask mandates.
text: Oregon and Washington State, two of the most successful states at limiting deaths and infections during the pandemic, lifted their statewide mask mandates on Saturday, making masks optional in most settings.

headline: Saudi Arabia Puts 81 to Death, Despite Promises to Curb Executions
text: CAIRO — Saudi Arabia said on Saturday that it had put 81 people to death in what was the kingdom’s largest mass execution in years, despite recent promises to curb its use of the death penalty.

headline: South Korea exceeds 380,000 new cases in a day shortly after its presidential election.
text: South Korea reported another record for daily new coronavirus cases over the weekend, reaching 383,665 known cases on Saturday, according to the government — a fresh reminder that cases have yet to peak during the current surge that is being fueled by the highly contagious Omicron variant. Public health experts had projected at the end of February that new cases would reach 350,000 a day by the end of March, and it was unclear whether predictions for a peak had been reset.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Two Years Into the Pandemic, Relief, Frustration and Fear as Mandates Ease
text: “Everyone is worn out. Everyone is exhausted. I am as well. But we lost 1,400 Americans yesterday to Covid and we’ll probably lost another 1,400 today. And I don’t think anything has happened that suggests to me that vaccine mandates and mask mandates should be lifted.”

headline: Corrections: March 13, 2022
text: An article on Page 18 this weekend about the movie “The Godfather” and its similarities to the real life mafia misspells the name of the author of “The Five Families: The Rise, Decline, and Resurgence of America’s Most Powerful Mafia Empires.” He is Selwyn Raab, not Rabb. The article also describes incorrectly a recording of two mobsters in 2005. The recordings were made in person, not over the telephone.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
text: SUNDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.

headline: Being on Leave Means Not Sending That 2 A.M. Email
text: Send questions about the office, money, careers and work-life balance to workfriend@nytimes.com. Include your name and location or request to remain anonymous. Letters may be edited.

headline: As a Crisis Hotline Grows, So Do Fears It Won’t Be Ready
text: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

headline: These Weed Sellers Aren’t Waiting for Permits: ‘Like a Dream Come True’
text: Wanting to invest in himself and be free of bosses, Terrence Gorham started selling customized T-shirts, hoodies and backpacks from a folding table in Washington Square Park a year ago. Like any good vendor, he noticed late last year when other tables started featuring something new: weed. Soon, he was offering pre-rolled joints and eighth-of-an-ounce pouches alongside his “Think Rich” clothing line.

headline: ‘The Driver Motioned for My Friend to Hand Over the Phone’
text: Dear Diary:

headline: When You Think About Investing, Don’t Think About the News
text: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

headline: Generation X Volunteers Want to Help You, and One Day Themselves, Age at Home
text: At 88, Susan McWhinney-Morse is a member of the Silent Generation, so named by some demographers partly for its heads-down, sleeves-up approach to hard work. She fits the industrious profile. But silent she is not.

headline: Naomi Osaka Brought to Tears by Heckler at Indian Wells
text: INDIAN WELLS, Calif. — Crying on court after being heckled by a spectator, Naomi Osaka was knocked out of the BNP Paribas Open in the second round on Saturday.

headline: The Week in Business: Economic Sanctions Take a Toll
text: More than two million people have fled Ukraine in the last two weeks as Russia’s invasion of the country claimed thousands of lives and cut off access to water and electricity in some cities. In response to the humanitarian crisis, more than 300 companies have withdrawn at least some operations in Russia, according to a list kept by the Yale School of Management. Retail companies closed stores, fast-food restaurants paused operations and business services firms removed Russian partners from their umbrella networks. But some of these measures have drawbacks. They could hurt Russian civilians or other countries that are allied against Russia. President Vladimir V. Putin accused the United States of waging “an economic war” against Russia on Wednesday and the next day told officials in a televised meeting that the assets of U.S. companies that pull out of Russia should be nationalized.

headline: On ‘S.N.L.,’ President Biden Seeks Help From TikTok Influencers
text: It was reported in The Washington Post this week that the Biden administration has been meeting with popular video creators from the social network TikTok and briefing them on the war in Ukraine, an unconventional move that could help the White House in its information battle … or get it made fun of relentlessly.

headline: The Year That Transformed Dickens (or Did It?)
text: THE TURNING POINT1851 — A Year That Changed Charles Dickens and the WorldBy Robert Douglas-Fairhurst

headline: Homes That Sold for Around $775,000
text: Each week, our survey of recent residential sales in New York City and the surrounding region focuses on homes that sold around a certain price point, allowing you to compare single-family homes, condos and co-ops in different locales.

headline: Eastern Orthodox Leaders Are Outspoken on Ukraine War. Except One.
text: Last week, more than a dozen religious and political leaders sat on the dais of the Ukrainian Orthodox Cathedral of Saint Volodymyr on the Upper West Side, listening to solemn prayers and fiery speeches denouncing Russia and extolling Ukrainian resistance to the invasion that began two weeks earlier.

headline: Talking Chaos, or Plotting a Conspiracy? The Debate in the Whitmer Kidnapping Trial.
text: GRAND RAPIDS, Mich. — Few people took the Covid-19 lockdown restrictions that swept the world in the spring of 2020 harder than the far-right extremist Adam Fox.

headline: U.K. vs. Oligarchs: ‘The Gloves Are Now Off’
text: LONDON — On Friday, the day after Britain blacklisted seven prominent Russian oligarchs, residents of the wealthy London borough of Kensington and Chelsea rolled a washing machine overflowing with fake pound notes in front of a multimillion-dollar townhouse belonging to the family of the president of Azerbaijan.

headline: California’s Ambitious High-Speed Rail at a Crossroads
text: FRESNO, Calif. — On an average day, 1,000 workers head to dozens of construction sites spread over 119 miles across California’s vast Central Valley.

headline: First Amendment Scholars Want to See the Media Lose These Cases
text: The lawyers and First Amendment scholars who have made it their life’s work to defend the well-established but newly threatened constitutional protections for journalists don’t usually root for the media to lose in court.

headline: Search Intensifies for Gunman in Homeless Shootings in 2 Cities
text: The police in New York City and Washington and federal investigators intensified their search on Monday for a gunman who they said had been targeting homeless people sleeping outdoors and had shot at least five men, two of them fatally.

headline: Missiles Fired From Iran Hit Near U.S. Consulate Site in Iraq
text: At least a dozen missiles fired from Iran struck near a United States Consulate compound being built outside the city of Erbil in the Kurdish region of Iraq early Sunday, according to Iraqi and U.S. officials.

headline: ‘Think of Groundhogs’: For Life Advice From a Grade Schooler, Press 2

headline: States Want to Ban Abortions Beyond Their Borders. Here’s What Pro-Choice States Can Do.

headline: It’s Time to Offer Russia an Offramp. China Can Help With That.
text: Casualties are mounting in Ukraine. Bombs continue to fall. More than 2 million refugees have fled the fighting.

headline: Government Is Flailing, in Part Because Liberals Hobbled It
text: There’s a strange story unfolding in Berkeley, Calif., right now. That may present as a tautology, but bear with me. This one provides a window into a problem that endangers us all.

headline: The Sunday Read: ‘What Rashida Tlaib Represents’
text: Rozina Ali profiles Rashida Tlaib, the 45-year-old second-term congresswoman from Detroit, who has risen from adverse circumstances to play a significant role in American politics, most notably bringing greater awareness to the ongoing conflict over Palestine.

headline: The War Next Door
text: USTRZYKI DOLNE, Poland — Polish people know the pain of being invaded. This is what an opera singer told me as she handed out hot stew to Ukrainian refugees in a tent near the mountainous border between Ukraine and Poland on a chilly night in early March. She had planned to go skiing. She came here instead.

headline: Poems in a Time of Crisis
text: Two weeks into the war, the Russians are still menacing my birth city, Odessa, in southwestern Ukraine. It sits on high bluffs above the Black Sea, its famous steps leading from the water to a square.

headline: N.C.A.A. Men’s Tournament Seedings Set as Spectacle Returns to March
text: When the N.C.A.A. men’s basketball tournament pairings were announced Sunday night, it served as one big welcome mat for the sport.

headline: The base attacked in western Ukraine has been a hub for foreign militaries.
text: The base outside Lviv that was attacked by Russian forces early on Sunday was a key link between Ukraine’s armed forces and Western militaries before the war — and has become an important logistics hub and training center for foreign fighters since Russia’s invasion began.

headline: Europe Awakens
text: Europe’s assertive response to Russia’s invasion of Ukraine has presented a possibility that was hard to imagine a month ago: the European Union as a superpower that can alter the global order, promoting liberal democratic values worldwide.

headline: A ‘Rock Wall’ Let the United States Flex Its Hockey Might
text: BEIJING — The tears started flowing from Jen Lee’s eyes the moment the horn sounded to signal that the United States had beaten Canada, 5-0, to win its fourth consecutive gold medal in Paralympic sled hockey.

headline: Jane Campion Wins Directors Guild Award for ‘The Power of the Dog’
text: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif. — The Directors Guild of America awarded its top prize for feature-film directing on Saturday night to Jane Campion for “The Power of the Dog,” making her the third woman ever to receive the award. Her victory also represents the first time in DGA history that women have won that award in back-to-back years, after Chloé Zhao took the prize in 2021 for “Nomadland.”

headline: N.C.A.A. Women’s Tournament Set With South Carolina at No. 1 Overall Seed
text: A 68-team field of stalwarts, potential spoilers and national tournament newcomers will play for the N.C.A.A. championship in Division I women’s basketball.

headline: Unsuk Chin on the Violin Concerto She Swore She’d Never Write
text: The 21st century has been a strong one for violin concertos. Think Jennifer Higdon, whose neo-Romantic showpiece for Hilary Hahn won the Pulitzer Prize in 2010. And Esa-Pekka Salonen, Thomas Adès, Harrison Birtwistle, Jörg Widmann (twice) and John Adams (the same).

headline: Critics Choice 2022: Complete List of Winners
text: The 27th Annual Critics Choice Awards, which gives out honors to both films and TV shows, were held on Sunday night.

headline: Brent Renaud, an American journalist, is killed in Ukraine.
text: Brent Renaud, an award-winning American filmmaker and journalist, was killed in Ukraine on Sunday while reporting in a suburb of the capital, Kyiv, according to Ukraine’s Interior Ministry.

headline: Trinity Church’s Conductor Put on Leave Amid Investigation
text: Trinity Wall Street, one of New York’s wealthiest and most powerful churches, said on Saturday that it was placing its high-profile director of music on leave as it investigates an allegation of sexual misconduct against him.

headline: What to Cook This Week
text: Good morning. How are you doing? I’m moved to ask that question every couple of months because I think it’s important to acknowledge that you might not be doing well at all. We are two years into the pandemic and some two weeks into the war in Ukraine. There’s heartbreak everywhere, and there are times for all of us when it seems too much to bear.

headline: With cases still rising in Hong Kong, 300,000 people are isolating at home, officials say.
text: HONG KONG — As many as 300,000 Hong Kong residents are isolating at home, the city’s leader said on Sunday, as officials scrambled to build mass quarantine centers and treatment facilities to house patients with even the mildest Covid-19 symptoms.

headline: How Readers Around the World Are Praying for Ukraine
text: Each morning over the past few weeks, I have woken up to the chirpy voices of my children. I’ve gotten them off to school and their daily activities, poured a cup of green tea and sat down to pray for Ukraine.

headline: How Likely Is Another Civil War?
text: To the Editor:

headline: Players to Watch in the Women’s N.C.A.A. Tournament
text: Between their highlight reel plays and hard-to-believe statistics, Aliyah Boston, Caitlin Clark and Paige Bueckers have become familiar not only to women’s college basketball fans but to many people with only a passing interest in sports.

headline: Players to Watch in the N.C.A.A. Men’s Tournament
text: When the N.C.A.A. men’s tournament starts with the play-in games on Tuesday and the round of 64 on Thursday, some of the most noticeable players to watch will come from schools like Bryant, South Dakota State and Seton Hall — not just from the top seeds.

headline: Tova Borgnine, Cosmetics Maven and QVC Star, Dies at 80
text: Tova Borgnine, the Norwegian-born cosmetics entrepreneur and home-shopping star who was known not just for selling beauty products but also for being the fifth wife and most enduring relationship of the actor Ernest Borgnine, died on Feb. 26 at her home in Chester County, Pa. She was 80.

headline: Brent Renaud, Crusading Filmmaker, Is Killed at 50
text: Brent Renaud, who with his brother, Craig, formed a Peabody Award-winning documentary film team that drew attention to human suffering, often working with major news organizations like The New York Times, was fatally shot in Irpin, a suburb of Kyiv, on Sunday. He was 50.

headline: The Key to a $4 Billion Fraud Case: A Banker Who Says He ‘Lied a Lot’
text: It seemed a facetious question, one intended to provoke the star witness: “Do you think you are good at lying?”

headline: Approval of travel insurance claims slows as the Omicron wave subsides.
text: Before the pandemic, Lauren Mack, 44, a writer based in New York City, “did not routinely purchase travel insurance,” she wrote in an email. Covid-19 convinced her otherwise, and of six trips taken since the onset of the pandemic, she has had to file claims for three — twice for weather delays and once because her travel companion tested positive for the virus. Two are still under review, and the first took nearly two months from claim to reimbursement.

headline: On a Stage 5,000 Miles Away, He Sings for His Family in Ukraine
text: Sometimes lately, when he hasn’t been rehearsing Verdi or Tchaikovsky at the Metropolitan Opera, or practicing Italian with a diction coach on Zoom, the bass-baritone Vladyslav Buialskyi takes out his phone and sends a one-word text message: “Mama.”

headline: Met Museum Names a Mexico City Architect to Lead a New Major Project
text: The Mexican architect Frida Escobedo, who at 38 was the youngest architect to design the Serpentine Pavilion in 2018, has been selected to design the Metropolitan Museum of Art’s new $500 million Modern and contemporary art wing, the museum announced on Sunday.

headline: At Chelsea, Nervous First Steps Into an Uncertain Future
text: LONDON — For the Chelsea fans who headed to Stamford Bridge for the team’s first home game since its world crumbled last week, signs of the club’s new, diminished circumstances were clear to see.

headline: Time is running out for civilians in Mariupol, Red Cross warns.
text: LVIV, Ukraine — At least 2,187 people in the coastal city of Mariupol have died since the start of the war, Ukraine’s government said Sunday, as the International Committee of the Red Cross warned that time was running out for hundreds of thousands of civilians still trapped in the besieged city.

headline: Unvaccinated M.L.B. players will not be allowed to play in Canada.
text: Major League Baseball players who are not vaccinated against the coronavirus will not be allowed to enter Canada to play games against the Toronto Blue Jays because of the country’s restrictions, and they will not be paid while the team is abroad as part of the sport’s new labor agreement.

headline: Renny Cushing, Relentless Foe of Death Penalty, Dies at 69
text: Robert R. Cushing Sr., a retired elementary-school teacher, was watching a basketball game on television at his home in New Hampshire in 1988 when he heard a knock at the door. When he answered it, a man fired two blasts from a sawed-off shotgun, killing him in front of his wife, and fled.

headline: Afghan Aviators Hide as Taliban Urge Them to Return to Duty
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — Last year, the three Afghan aviators served in the elite Special Mission Wing of the Afghan Air Force. Trained by Americans to fight the Taliban from the air, they were some of the Afghan military’s most elite troops.

headline: Brent Renaud, an American filmmaker killed in Ukraine, captured the human toll of war.
text: When Brent Renaud, an award-winning American filmmaker and journalist, was killed in Ukraine on Sunday, he was there to do what he had done throughout his career: bear witness to the world’s most dangerous stories.

headline: Review: ‘A Song of Songs’ Makes a Sacrament of Remembrance
text: A few sheets of colored tissue paper, weighted down by a trinket to keep them from fluttering off. This is what audience members find on their seats upon arrival at “A Song of Songs,” Agnes Borinsky’s new theater piece inspired by the biblical Song of Songs, and it’s something of a puzzle. What to do with them?

headline: Biden Administration Fights in Court to Uphold Some Trump-Era Immigration Policies
text: WASHINGTON — President Biden promised to unravel the “moral and national shame” of the immigration policies enacted by President Donald J. Trump. But that was hardly the position Mr. Biden’s lawyers took in a federal courtroom earlier this year.

headline: Seven Steps to Destroy a Democracy
text: We are now living through a fully fledged attack on nonwhite power in this country, as conservative white people assert their authority. Until now, the effects of this crusade were somewhat unclear. Data needed to be collected after new conservative laws and policies had gone into effect.

headline: The Skiing Aigners Are a Nation Unto Themselves
text: YANQING, China — The 2022 Winter Paralympics ended Sunday with China winning, by far, the most medals, 61, followed by the undaunted Ukrainian team and Canada.

headline: Ukraine’s energy minister says power has been restored at Chernobyl nuclear plant.
text: Ukraine’s energy minister said Sunday that power supply has been restored at the Chernobyl nuclear power plant, which Russian troops have occupied since late February.

headline: Ukrainian refugees find shelter, and a hearty welcome for their pets, in Romania.
text: SUCEAVA, Romania — Viktor and Rachel Borovic were very grateful to be given a hot meal at a church in Suceava after they crossed from Ukraine into Romania, but they had to turn down the offer of a bed for the night. Their dog, Busia, and their cat, Coco, named after Coco Chanel, were not allowed to stay.

headline: ‘Things Will Only Get Worse.’ Putin’s War Sends Russians Into Exile.
text: ISTANBUL — They lined up at A.T.M.s, desperate for cash after Visa and Mastercard suspended operations in Russia, swapping intelligence on where they could still get dollars. At Istanbul cafes, they sat quietly studying Telegram chats or Google Maps on their phones. They organized support groups to help other Russian exiles find housing.

headline: Russia Asked China for Military and Economic Aid for Ukraine War, U.S. Officials Say
text: WASHINGTON — Russia asked China to give it military equipment and support for the war in Ukraine after President Vladimir V. Putin began a full-scale invasion last month, according to U.S. officials.

headline: Pro Boxing Gains Another Father-Son Duo
text: During a Showtime boxing broadcast in February, one of the network’s analysts, Raul Marquez, praised a Houston welterweight as a “tough guy” who had sparred with his son Giovanni, a promising amateur.

headline: Former President Obama tests positive for the coronavirus.
text: Former President Barack Obama said Sunday that he tested positive for the coronavirus and has a scratchy throat but is otherwise fine.

headline: Rampaging Camel Kills Two Men at a Tennessee Farm
text: Two men were killed by a camel that had gotten loose at a farm in Tennessee on Thursday, the authorities said.

headline: Your Monday Briefing: Deadly Airstrikes in Ukraine’s West
text: Russia launched a barrage of airstrikes at a military base that had served as a hub for Western arms shipments near the Polish border, killing at least 35 people and wounding at least 134. Videos show the moment of the attack and the aftermath.

headline: Frustrated With Utilities, Some Californians Are Leaving the Grid
text: NEVADA CITY, Calif. — In the Gold Rush, Northern California attracted prospectors looking for financial independence. Now, this area is at the vanguard of a new movement — people seeking to use only the energy they produce themselves.

headline: Review: In ‘Misdemeanor Dream,’ Speaking to the Unseen
text: The fairies have stories to share. At least the ones in “Misdemeanor Dream,” who tell tales in English and Native languages, but also via movement and dance, of the births of constellations, the celestial romance that begets all sentient life. But the thicket of music, overlapping dialogue, sounds and projections in this experimental work, presented by La MaMa and the Indigenous feminist theater ensemble Spiderwoman Theater, doesn’t always come together to convey these enchanting stories; in fact, this patchwork often makes the show indecipherable.

headline: The ‘Cohen Tax’ Doesn’t Scare the Owner It Is Named For
text: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — Steven A. Cohen has been a Major League Baseball club owner only since October 2020. In that short time, he has dramatically changed the trajectory of his team, the Mets, and its spending, the latter of which directly led to a new league payroll tax nicknamed after him.

headline: Booms, Smoke and Fire Signal Horror of Russian Attack on Base
text: NOVOYAVORIVSK, Ukraine — Hours after Russian missiles decimated a military base near the Polish border on Sunday, soldiers in camouflage were still being wheeled out of an overwhelmed nearby hospital on stretchers, many in so much pain they could only turn their heads to reveal eyes stricken with fear.

headline: ‘The Power of the Dog’ Wins Best Film at Wide-Open BAFTAs
text: LONDON — “The Power of the Dog,” Jane Campion’s tense Western about two clashing brothers on a Montana ranch, starring Benedict Cumberbatch and Jesse Plemons, was the big winner at the EE British Academy Film Awards in London on Sunday night.

headline: Critics Choice Awards 2022 Red Carpet Photos
text: The 27th annual Critics Choice Awards may shine some light on the Oscars race. See the stars as they made their way down the red carpet.

headline: A Good One Is Square
text: MONDAY PUZZLE — Today’s puzzle is a debut by Stephen Hiltner, an editor and photojournalist here at The Times. Mr. Hiltner may be the 19th constructor to make a debut in 2022, but he’s certainly the first Times employee that I’ve seen make a crossword debut during my own (admittedly brief) tenure here. He very kindly contributed the photo at the top of this column, so you can probably understand my bewilderment that someone can be so talented at such different things as crossword construction and photography. I recommend checking out the photojournalism projects linked in Mr. Hiltner’s notes below.

headline: How Does It End? A Way Out of the Ukraine War Proves Elusive.
text: WASHINGTON — The United States accurately predicted the start of the war in Ukraine, sounding the alarm that an invasion was imminent despite Moscow’s denials and Europe’s skepticism. Predicting how it might end is proving far more difficult.

headline: Shelling damages a revered monastery, and injures some seeking shelter there.
text: KYIV, Ukraine — Fighting has damaged a 16th-century monastery and cave complex that is a highly revered Orthodox Christian site for believers in both Russia and Ukraine, according to a church statement, in an incident sure to drive a deeper wedge between the Ukrainian and Russian branches of the church.

headline: William Hurt, Oscar-Winning Leading Man of the 1980s, Dies at 71
text: William Hurt, who became a hot Hollywood commodity with his performance as a hapless lawyer in “Body Heat” in 1981 and within a few years had won the best-actor Oscar for the 1985 film “Kiss of the Spider Woman,” in which he portrayed a gay man sharing a Brazilian prison cell with a revolutionary, died at his home in Portland, Ore., on Sunday. He was 71.

headline: Oil Prices Drop as Market Volatility Eases
text: Oil prices slid at the start of trading on Monday morning, a respite from the volatility of recent weeks as Russia’s assault on Ukraine grinds on.

headline: Russian Airstrike at NATO’s Doorstep Raises Fears of Expanded War
text: LVIV, Ukraine — Russia launched a barrage of airstrikes on Sunday against a military base in western Ukraine where American troops had trained Ukrainian forces just weeks earlier, bringing the war 11 miles from the border with Poland, where NATO forces are stationed on high alert.

headline: Tom Brady Says He Will Return to N.F.L. and Buccaneers
text: After less than six weeks of retirement, it appears that Tom Brady is back.

headline: Broadway Singing Coach, 87, Dies After Attack on Street
text: [Update: Barbara Maier Gustern, who was pushed to the ground on Thursday near her Manhattan apartment building, died of her injuries on Tuesday morning, according to a police official and relatives.]

headline: Your Monday Briefing
text: Russia launched a barrage of attacks against a military base in Ukraine yesterday, bringing the war 11 miles from the border with Poland. About 1,000 foreigners who had come to help Ukraine were believed to have been training at the base. “The entire sky was in flames,” one witness said.

headline: What’s on TV This Week: ‘Phoenix Rising’ and ‘Welcome to Flatch’
text: Between network, cable and streaming, the modern television landscape is a vast one. Here are some of the shows, specials and movies coming to TV this week, March 14-20. Details and times are subject to change.

headline: Kim Jong-un Is Just Getting Started
text: You could be forgiven for forgetting about North Korea, which went quiet for a stretch, locked in self-imposed isolation for two years during the pandemic while U.S. attention diverted to other crises (like the perilous fate of Ukraine).

headline: Need a Haircut? Pay What You Wish at This Barbershop
text: Good morning. It’s Monday. You did remember to set your clock ahead, didn’t you? Today we’ll look at what happens when customers can pay what they can. We’ll also look at how New York’s State Capitol, dormant during the pandemic, is coming back to life.

headline: Foxconn, which assembles Apple’s iPhones, suspends production at factories in Shenzhen, China, because of a lockdown.

headline: How High Oil Prices Threaten a California Plastic Container Business
text: Long before President Vladimir V. Putin unleashed his war on Ukraine, Mosharraf Khalid was already contending with an expensive, bewildering and unrelenting assortment of problems afflicting the global supply chain.

headline: A Fatal Crossing on the Northern Border
text: PEMBINA, N.D. — The air temperature was pushing 20 below zero and howling winds were whipping up blinding snow one morning in January when U.S. Border Patrol agents in North Dakota spotted five human forms moving through the barren borderland where America and Canada meet.

headline: Which Coronavirus Vaccine Will Work in the Youngest Children?
text: WASHINGTON — Over the past 10 months, as tens of millions of children and teenagers received the Pfizer-BioNTech vaccine, the companies’ main rival, Moderna, sat on the sidelines, its shot limited to adults.

headline: Climate Change Is Killing Her Country. Who Will Decide if It Lives?
